newsitem.title: UK: LVMH seeks arbitration on Guinness merger.
newsitem.headline: LVMH seeks arbitration on Guinness merger.

text.p: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton AS said on Friday it has submitted a request for arbitration to the International Chamber of Commerce in its dispute with Guinness Plc over a proposed merger between Guinness and Grand Metropolitan Plc.
French drinks and luxury goods company LVMH is the biggest shareholder in Guinness with a 14.2 percent stake and has opposed the planned merger.

The company wants the chamber to decide if the deal represents a change of control at Guinness. The arbitration concerns a dispute over whether the merger constitutes a "control event" under the terms of agreements between LVMH and Guinness.
LVMH argues that under the terms of agreements signed with Guinness a "control event" would enable LVMH to operate its joint ventures with Guinness independently.
The company has argued that the terms would also allow it to market Guinness brands in key markets like the United States and the Far East for up to 10 years.

LVMH voted against the proposed 24 billion pound merger between Guinness and GrandMet, the largest in British corporate history, saying it would create a food and drinks giant with few synergies and fail to increase shareholder value.
LVMH chairman Bernard Arnault argues that only the wines and spirits of the two groups are complementary and sees more value in merging the drinks activities of LVMH, Guinness and possibly GrandMet.

LVMH drinks include Moet & Chandon champagne and Hennessey cognacs. Guinness owns the Johnny Walker and Dewar whiskies and Gordon's Gin brands, while GrandMet has Smirnoff vodka, J&B whisky and Bailey's liqueur.
Guinness argues that that the merger does not constitute the kind of "control event" allowing LVMH to exercise the rights because it is a merger rather than a takeover of Guinness by GrandMet.

Under the terms of the proposed merger Guinness shareholders will retain their shares in Guinness which is renamed GMG Brands, while GrandMet shareholders receive one GMG Brands share for every one GrandMet share.

If the deal takes place GrandMet shares will be delisted and the name Guinness changed to GMG Brands. The GMG Brands board will be made up of five directors drawn from each company and a joint chairman from each side.
